author: By Jill Cowan
title: They Checked Out Pride Books in Protest. It Backfired.
description: Two San Diego residents cleared out the Pride month display at their library and said such materials shouldn’t be available to children, one of several recent clashes over L.G.B.T.Q. issues in California.
content: Adrianne Peterson, the manager of the Rancho Peñasquitos branch of the San Diego Public Library, was actually a little embarrassed by the modest size of her Pride Month display in June. Between staff vacations and organizing workshops for graduating high school students, it had fallen through the cracks and fell short of what she had hoped to offer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Wildfires Imperil Greek Isle of Rhodes, Forcing Big Relocation
description: Greek Coast Guard vessels were dispatched to rescue visitors and residents trapped in threatened seaside villages on the large island, a leading tourist destination. Some fled in their bathing suits.
content: Greek Coast Guard vessels on Saturday evacuated hundreds of tourists and locals trapped in seaside villages on Rhodes that were threatened by five-day-old wildfires, moving them to safer parts of the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Braidwood
title: England has been strong but shaky going into this tournament.
description: It is an interesting time for the England women’s team, which arrives at the Women’s World Cup among the tournament favorites but also in perhaps its most uncertain state after two years of largely smooth sailing.
content: It is an interesting time for the England women’s team, which arrives at the Women’s World Cup among the tournament favorites but also in perhaps its most uncertain state after two years of largely smooth sailing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: How Do the White House’s A.I. Commitments Stack Up?
description: Seven leading A.I. companies made eight promises about what they’ll do with their technology. Our columnist sizes up their potential impact.
content: This week, the White House announced that it had secured “voluntary commitments” from seven leading A.I. companies to manage the risks posed by artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Stars Muted No More at British Open, Rahm Roars Up Leaderboard
description: Jon Rahm’s 63 was a record for an Open at Royal Liverpool, but Brian Harman will enter Sunday with a five-shot lead.
content: Every major tournament has the cruel, curt power to humble golf’s stars. Rory McIlroy at the Masters. Justin Thomas at the P.G.A. Championship. Phil Mickelson at the U.S. Open (OK, make that a lot of them).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Malaysia Halts Music Festival After Kiss Between Bandmates Onstage
description: The episode comes as rights groups have warned of growing intolerance against lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people in the country, where homosexuality is a crime.
content: Malaysia’s government halted a music festival in the capital, Kuala Lumpur, on Saturday, a day after the frontman of the British pop rock band The 1975 kissed a male bandmate onstage and criticized the country’s anti-L.G.B.T. laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: Whatever You Think of the Movies, the Barbenheimer Memes Are Glorious
description: This explosion of fan-driven creativity is so much more entertaining than mere marketing could ever be.
content: Recently, I bought a T-shirt from Rob Sheridan, the co-founder of the design company Glitch Goods and the former art director for the industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails. It’s a sleeveless black muscle shirt that has an eyeless melting Barbie doll face dripping with blood and set against a fiery backdrop and says, ominously, “This Barbie opened the ark of the covenant … She betrayed the word of God.” Mr. Sheridan promoted the shirt to coincide with the same-day opening of Greta Gerwig’s “Barbie” and Christopher Nolan’s “Oppenheimer,” a new, unofficial phenomenon the moviegoing masses have called “Barbenheimer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Mike Reynolds, Champion of California’s Three-Strikes Law, Dies at 79
description: The murder of his daughter sent him on a successful quest to push for tougher sentencing at a time when violent crime was a top concern nationwide.
content: Mike Reynolds, a California photographer who, after his daughter was murdered in 1992, became a driving force behind stricter sentencing reforms in his state, including its contentious three-strikes law, died on July 9 in Fresno, Calif. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amby Burfoot
title: The Real Power of Super Shoes Could Be Supercharged Training
description: Super shoes are ubiquitous for both track and road races. But does the real benefit come from training in them?
content: One month before the year’s biggest track and field event, a dizzying number of fleet-footed performances have lit up local and professional meets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: How the Hunt for a Lioness Near Berlin Turned Into a Wild Boar Chase
description: The heavily armed search that upended the southern edge of the German capital met an anti-climactic end — and left some scratching their heads: “A wild boar doesn’t really look like a lion.”
content: A frenzied hunt for a loose lioness on the outskirts of Berlin that prompted the deployment of helicopters, drones and night-vision-goggle-clad police officers came to an unexpected end after the authorities announced that it was likely a case of mistaken identity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 22, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 22, 2023.
content: An article on Page 34 this weekend about Wikipedia and artificial intelligence refers imprecisely to what Margaret Mitchell has said about why she was fired from Google. She has said she was fired for criticizing how the company treated colleagues working on bias in A.I., not for criticizing the direction of its work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
title: In Belarus, the Protests Were Three Years Ago. The Crackdown Is Never-Ending.
description: Aleksandr G. Lukashenko brutally repressed those who opposed his claim of re-election as president. The crackdown on dissent has only deepened since.
content: The recent high school graduate selected her wardrobe carefully as she headed off to a summer folk festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Lawyers Say Helping Asylum Seekers in Border Custody Is Nearly Impossible
description: The Biden administration changed the way “credible fear” interviews are conducted and raised the bar for who is eligible to seek asylum.
content: In the first weeks after President Biden’s new border policies were put in place, his administration recorded a sharp drop in the number of people allowed to apply for asylum after crossing into the United States illegally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: 11 Killed in Suspected Arson in Mexico Club
description: Prosecutors say a man hurled a firebomb at the bar after being ejected. Mexico has struggled to tamp down on raging violent crime.
content: Eleven people were killed and four injured in a suspected arson attack at a bar in the northern border city of San Luis Río Colorado, Sonora, on Saturday morning, Mexican authorities said, as the country continues to struggle with violent crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: An All-Star Lineup
description: To boost its sagging fortunes, The Times introduced six new daily sections in the late 1970s. One of them was SportsMonday, a visual knockout.
content: Forty-five years is an eternity in the news business. With the recent announcement by The New York Times that the newsroom was disbanding its sports department, 1978 seems even more distant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David George Haskell
title: The Birds Are Singing, but Not for Me
description: Evolution’s curse of creeping deafness changes how a biologist experiences nature.
content: Animal sounds are my connection to the changing seasons. Every week, a new voice appears or fades. Early winter arrives with the chip of juncos. The chitter of nestling bluebirds signals the onset of summer, closely followed by the first cicadas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Aural Surgery
description: Tread lightly through Chandi Deitmer’s complex crossword operation.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Richard Barancik, Last of the World War II Monuments Men, Dies at 98
description: He played a role in the celebrated Allied operation to preserve European artworks and cultural treasures stolen by the Nazis.
content: Richard Barancik, the last surviving member of the Allied unit known as the Monuments Men and Women, which during and after World War II preserved a vast amount of European artworks and cultural treasures that had been looted and hidden by Nazi Germany, died on July 14 in Chicago. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Kidnapped Girl’s ‘Help Me!’ Sign Leads to Her Rescue
description: A passer-by saw the girl’s sign at a parking lot in Long Beach, Calif., after a 61-year-old man had taken her from Texas days earlier, officials said.
content: A 13-year-old Texas girl was kidnapped, driven across multiple state lines and then rescued after she held up a handmade “Help Me!” sign in a California parking lot, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Lionel Messi Ventures Into Charted Territory
description: The Argentine star’s signing is seen as a way to push soccer into the American mainstream. But it’s already there.
content: Tempting Lionel Messi to the United States could not solely be a matter of money. The money had to be right, of course. It had to be competitive. It was, Jorge Mas knew, perfectly possible that his attempt to persuade Messi, the greatest player of his generation, to sign for Inter Miami would fail because of money. But it would not succeed because of it. Not exclusively, anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Four Are Missing After Severe Flooding in Nova Scotia
description: Residents were evacuated, numerous roads washed out and many cars left abandoned in the region, officials said on Saturday.
content: Four people were missing on Saturday after torrential flooding swept through Nova Scotia, Canada, forcing many residents to evacuate their homes, while others had to be rescued by boat, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: ‘How To With John Wilson’ Is Ending. What Will He Do Now?
description: Now that the filmmaker’s HBO series is wrapping up, would he rule out directing a season of “The Bachelor”?
content: John Wilson likes trilogies. “There are only three seasons of ‘Jackass,’” he pointed out during an interview this month from his home in Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Booz Allen Pays $377.5 Million to Settle Government Billing Case
description: The consulting firm was accused of falsely charging for expenses that should have been paid under its nongovernment contracts from 2011 to 2021.
content: The consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton has agreed to pay $377.5 million to settle a federal lawsuit that accused it of falsely billing the U.S. government, the Justice Department said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Pitcher
title: A Wedding in 2025? Not Astrologically Ideal for Me.
description: Social media is giving a lift to the centuries-old practice of looking to the stars to decide on the exact time, date and location of a couple’s big day.
content: Last year, Alice Bell told Jesse Zannino that he needed to propose by May 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Moment of Truth for Our Liar in Chief
description: Has Florida Man met his match in an Ironman?
content: WASHINGTON — A man is running to run the government he tried to overthrow while he was running it, even as he is running to stay ahead of the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How to Work Out Safely in the Heat
description: As record-breaking temperatures continue, can you still exercise outside? Possibly, but you have to be careful.
content: As unprecedented heat waves become more common, exercisers increasingly have to weigh the joys versus the risks of an outdoor workout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: What’s the Status of Flaunting Your Status?
description: In the world of the ultrawealthy, luxury is only quiet if you don’t know what to listen for.
content: In what now seems the quaint era of Truman Capote’s baroque social diagrams, what distinguished the truly wealthy from the merely rich was the better vegetables they served: “tiny ones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Extreme Heat Shows the Need for Another Kind of Climate Investment
description: Almost all climate finance focuses on mitigating climate change. But money is increasingly pouring in to helping people adapt to the effects of global warming.
content: Good morning. In today’s newsletter: Extreme heat highlights the need for another kind of climate investment; A.I. puts shadow libraries in the spotlight; and Aly Wagner, a co-founder of a new women’s soccer team, talks about the money in women’s sports. (Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Jamie Foxx Says He Is ‘Coming Back’ After Hospitalization
description: The actor posted a video on Instagram after being largely absent from public life since his family said he was hospitalized in April.
content: Jamie Foxx, the comedian, Oscar-winning actor and Grammy-winning singer, said in a video on Instagram that he could return to work after he was hospitalized with an undisclosed illness in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Tim Scott Awaits His Moment. But Will It Come?
description: The South Carolina senator is gaining in early-voting states and has money, a positive message and a compelling story. Now he needs to take on the Republican front-runners.
content: He is rising in the polls and turning heads in Iowa and New Hampshire, behind heavy spending on ads that play to voters’ appetite for a leader who is upbeat and positive in a dark political moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: A Story of Arab Loss Comes to Life at a Kibbutz in Israel
description: A museum founded by pioneering Zionists has been hosting a sweeping retrospective of Palestinian art.
content: For years, the kibbutz of Ein Harod has prospered in the Jezreel Valley, a fertile plain in northern Israel still scarred by the convulsions that accompanied the creation of the Jewish state 75 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Sophia Smith Has Been Ready for Her World Cup Moment
description: Smith had two goals and an assist in her debut in the tournament. And she believes, along with her teammates, that there could have been more.
content: In the weeks before the Women’s World Cup, Sophia Smith admitted that she wanted to be the first United States player to score a goal in the tournament. Of course she did. Like every great athlete, she has long envisioned herself as a star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: For One Democrat, the Price of Bucking Her Party Is a Flood of Bad Reviews
description: Representative Marie Gluesenkamp Pérez’s automobile repair business has become a target of online trolls on the left after she opposed President Biden’s student loan forgiveness initiative.
content: Dean’s Car Care, an auto repair shop in Portland, Ore., used to regularly rack up five stars and gushing accolades on Yelp and Google Reviews for its reliable and friendly service.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Vegans Make Smaller Mark on the Planet Than Others
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 22, 2023
content: “This reinforces the message that the amount of meat we consume is strongly related with our environmental footprint.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: Diana Athill’s Only Novel, About Coming of Age in 1950s London
description: First published in 1967, “Don’t Look at Me Like That” follows a young woman from her unpopular teenage years to uncertain adulthood.
content: Twenty-three years ago, Diana Athill wrote “Stet,” a memoir of her life as an editor in which she outlined the pleasures of her profession. “It was like removing layers of crumpled brown paper from an awkwardly shaped parcel,” she writes of honing a text, “and revealing the attractive present which it contained.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: A Thrilling, Rediscovered Nina Simone Set, and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Snoh Aalegra, DeYarmond Edison, Explosions in the Sky and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Welcome to Barbenheimer Weekend
description: You have little choice but to surrender to the dark and the air conditioning and the allure of two of the summer’s biggest movies.
content: Start the day with the darker fare: Christopher Nolan’s moody “Oppenheimer,” about the physicist who ran the Los Alamos Laboratory during the development of the atomic bomb. A morning screening is best, so you can get some fresh air, some sustenance other than Milk Duds, clear your head before Greta Gerwig’s “live-action, you-go-girl fantasia,” “Barbie,” the second half of the double feature known, for better or worse, as “Barbenheimer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Stagnation of Ron DeSantis
description: The great non-Trump hope has faltered. He’s still the only contender with a path.
content: Is it possible to rapidly “reboot” a struggling presidential campaign? Pundits have to hope so, since otherwise our advice-giving beat becomes a bit irrelevant. But thinking back over recent primary candidacies that seemed to sag and then recovered, from John Kerry in 2004 to John McCain in 2008 to Joe Biden in 2020, it’s hard to identify brilliant strategic pivots. Instead what you see is candidates with fundamental strengths who hung around until events conspired to make those strengths more relevant, their opponents’ weaknesses more manifest, and their campaigns suddenly triumphant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Miller
title: How a YouTube Sensation Spends His Sundays
description: Marc Rebillet, who became known during pandemic lockdowns for livestreaming improvised songs featuring electronic loops, takes his grooves to the streets.
content: In the spring of 2020, Marc Rebillet’s improvised, solo funk shows, livestreamed on YouTube and Facebook from his apartment, became a lockdown sensation. Wearing a bathrobe and boxers, Mr. Rebillet posted a phone number and asked callers to suggest a word or theme that he’d use to write anthemic songs on the fly, belting them out in a power baritone. The tunes were danceable, subversive and hilariously raunchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Beijing Offers Love, but Chinese Entrepreneurs Aren’t Buying It
description: The government’s new 31-point guidelines meant to inspire confidence feel empty to businesspeople after a three-year clampdown and no concrete changes.
content: In the darkest moments of the financial crisis in 2008, former Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao lectured a group of U.S. government officials and business executives in New York. “In the face of economic difficulties,” he said, “confidence is more precious than gold.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: 3 Dead in Listeria Outbreak in Washington State
description: Health officials said five cases of listeriosis in Puget Sound were probably caused by the same unidentified food source. All of those infected were older than 60.
content: Health officials in Washington State said on Friday that three people had died and two had been hospitalized in the Puget Sound area after contracting food-borne listeria infections in what appeared to be an outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen to This American Life: House on Loon Lake
description: The search for a mysterious family who disappeared without a trace.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Mike Pence on the Campaign Trail
description: The former vice president has made misleading claims about abortion, fiscal policy and military spending.
content: Since beginning his long-shot presidential campaign in June, former Vice President Mike Pence has struggled to gain traction among Republican primary voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: ‘Conan,’ ‘Goodfellas’ and MTV: How Tony Bennett Revived His Career
description: Mr. Bennett’s career went downhill in the 1970s, as drug and financial problems haunted him. Then his son became his manager, and everything took a rags-to-riches turn.
content: In the 1970s, Tony Bennett’s career and life were in disarray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Far Right May Rise as Kingmaker in Spanish Election
description: A messier political landscape has lent leverage to the extremes, leaving a hard-right party with a chance to share power for the first time since Franco.
content: If Spain’s national elections on Sunday turn out as most polls and analysts suggest, mainstream conservatives may come out on top but need allies on the political fringe to govern, ushering the first hard-right party into power since the Franco dictatorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: The Question After Every Mass Shooting: How Much Do We Deserve to Know?
description: A court in Nashville may decide whether releasing the musings of a killer could help prevent future losses, despite adding to survivors’ pain.
content: After every mass shooting it comes: recordings of pleading 911 calls, photos of the scene, grim evidence released by law enforcement. This tsunami of investigative detail could save lives, but it inflicts fresh agony on the families of the dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isayen Herrera, Sheyla Urdaneta and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
title: Venezuela’s Oil Industry Is Broken. Now It’s Breaking the Environment.
description: Gas flares and leaking pipelines from Venezuela’s once-booming oil industry, hobbled by U.S. sanctions and mismanagement, are polluting towns and a major lake.
content: Each morning, José Aguilera inspects the leaves of his banana and coffee plants on his farm in eastern Venezuela and calculates how much he can harvest — almost nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Extreme Challenges
description: Buckle up for Robert Logan’s tough Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Robert Logan’s second crossword for The Times, and his first themeless, after a Friday debut last August (First themeless? That’s right. If you can think of a themed Friday puzzle of late, you’re probably thinking of Mr. Logan’s, because they’re as rare as hen’s teeth). This grid is notable for its low word count and its great looks. I think it resembles a symbol for a tropical storm or clothes spinning in a dryer, and I tumbled through it several times before I completed my solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Challenged by Tech and Market Forces, Independent Bookshops Bounce Back
description: Their demise was long predicted and pandemic closings were a heavy blow, but many local shops are thriving again.
content: While traveling around Canada on assignment, I usually try to visit museums and art galleries and, when they’re available, local bookshops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: Japan Says It Can Make Coal Cleaner. Critics Say Its Plan Is ‘Almost Impossible.’
description: Japan says that by blending ammonia with coal in its boilers, it can make coal less damaging to the planet. But the technology faces many hurdles.
content: The world’s advanced economies have committed to phasing out coal over the next seven years. But not Japan, which stands alone in insisting it can make coal less damaging to the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: How a Drug Maker Profited by Slow-Walking a Promising H.I.V. Therapy
description: Gilead delayed a new version of a drug, allowing it to extend the patent life of a blockbuster line of medications, internal documents show.
content: In 2004, Gilead Sciences decided to stop pursuing a new H.I.V. drug. The public explanation was that it wasn’t sufficiently different from an existing treatment to warrant further development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: Huge Protest March Reaches Jerusalem After 5-Day Trek From Tel Aviv
description: Tens of thousands of protesters reached Jerusalem on Saturday, some having walked 40 miles from Tel Aviv. The march highlighted the depth of opposition to a government plan to restrain the judiciary.
content: A miles-long column of antigovernment demonstrators marched into Jerusalem on Saturday evening, turning the main road to the city into a sea of blue-and-white Israeli flags, to protest the far-right government’s plan to limit judicial power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
title: A Decade Ago, Jeff Bezos Bought a Newspaper. Now He’s Paying Attention to It Again.
description: The Amazon founder, who purchased The Washington Post for $250 million in 2013, has taken a more active role in the paper’s operations this year.
content: During his tenure as executive editor at The Washington Post, Martin Baron ran into a persistent problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: With Israel, It’s Time to Start Discussing the Unmentionable
description: Does it make sense for the United States to provide $3.8 billion annually to another rich country, indefinitely?
content: Israel is in the headlines, evoking tumultuous debate. Yet one topic remains largely unmentionable, so let me gingerly raise it: Is it time to think about phasing out American aid for Israel down the road?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Risks of One of the Most Severe Tools in America’s Foreign Policy Arsenal
description: Punishing countries with harsh sanctions rarely works as intended without clear goals for lifting them.
content: There is nearly universal consensus that certain egregious violations of international laws and norms demand a forceful and concerted response. Think only, for example, of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine or the development of nuclear weapons capabilities in Iran and North Korea. Harsh economic sanctions have long been viewed as the answer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Complicated Stories of Affirmative Action
description: Readers react to John McWhorter’s account of how it affected his education and career. Also: Race and artistic achievement.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Can This Man Fix France’s Women’s Team?
description: Hervé Renard has led two men’s teams to the World Cup. But in taking over his country’s talented but troubled women’s squad, he may have his toughest job yet.
content: The banner hangs just beneath the central staircase of the elegant hotel that has been taken over by the France women’s national team for the World Cup. Hervé Renard wanted to make sure no one in his squad could miss it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacqui Germain
title: Student Loans Come Due Again: Many Borrowers Will Lose a Lifeline
description: The payment pause freed up money that gave people breathing room — or allowed them to help family members in need. They will soon have to budget for that expense.
content: With her student loan payments on hold for three years, Ashley Dorn, a public school music teacher, found another use for the money she saved during the moratorium. She used the extra cash to pay off $10,000 in credit card debt, a bill that had been nagging at her for a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: How Can I Force My Co-op Board to Fix a Ceiling Leak?
description: Co-op boards have a fiduciary responsibility to take care of their buildings, but sometimes shareholders must compel them to act.
content: Q: We bought an apartment on the top floor of a co-op in Yorkville in April 2020. After living there for a while, we moved out and now rent it out to a tenant. Once or twice a year, the ceiling leaks during rainstorms. We always notify the super and the management company, the super “finds” a problem and “fixes” it, our ceiling is patched and we go on with our lives. But it keeps happening. I’m worried there might be mold or structural damage, and apparently it leaked into the elevator shaft. What can I do to pressure them to get a more thorough evaluation and permanent fix?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Bamberger
title: At the British Open, a Mom’s Influence Looms Large for Many Golfers
description: Golf has long had a tradition of fathers and sons, but when the British Open was last held at Royal Liverpool in 2014, Rory McIlroy put golf’s moms on equal footing.
content: In the beginning, there was Old Tom Morris and his son, Tommy, both of St. Andrews. The father won the British Open — the only championship then — four times and his namesake son won it four times, too. Yes, wet wool, 19th-century golf, in all its paternalistic glory. The men marched off the first tee and into a heavy sea wind and nobody knew when, or if, they would come back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Would You Drink Wastewater? What if It Was Beer?
description: In an era of drought, turning treated wastewater into drinking water may be the future. Utility companies are working with breweries to get people past the “ick factor.”
content: Epic OneWater Brew looks like your classic hipster craft beer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: No Opposition. No Choice. Cambodia’s Election Paves Way for Dynastic Rule.
description: Hun Sen, the prime minister for nearly four decades, applied familiar tactics ahead of Sunday’s vote to guarantee he would run virtually unopposed, and set the stage for his son to rule the country.
content: Cambodian voters went to the polls Sunday in a Parliamentary election that could set the stage for the first change in leadership since Hun Sen became prime minister nearly four decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Hurricane Don Forms, Becoming the First of the Atlantic Season
description: The storm is the first Atlantic hurricane of the season, but it does not pose a threat to land, meteorologists said.
content: Tropical Storm Don strengthened into a hurricane on Saturday, making it the first of the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: UPS Contract Talks Go Down to the Wire as a Possible Strike Looms
description: With the Teamsters contract set to expire Aug. 1, pay for part-time workers is a major hurdle. A walkout could rattle the U.S. economy.
content: Barely a week before the contract for more than 325,000 United Parcel Service workers expires, union and company negotiators have yet to reach an agreement to avert a strike that could knock the American economy off stride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Nico Muhly Modernizes Monteverdi With ‘Irreverent Veneration’
description: Muhly has reorchestrated Monteverdi’s foundational “L’Orfeo” for a new production at Santa Fe Opera.
content: When a new production of Monteverdi’s “L’Orfeo” premieres at Santa Fe Opera on July 29, something about it might seem slightly odd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Patricia Mazzei and Albert Sun
title: The Steep Cost of Ron DeSantis’s Vaccine Turnabout
description: Once a vaccine advocate, the Florida governor lost his enthusiasm for the shot before the Delta wave sent Covid hospitalizations and deaths soaring. It’s a grim chapter he now leaves out of his rosy retelling of his pandemic response.
content: On a Saturday in September 2020, with Covid-19 killing more than 600 Americans daily and hundreds of thousands of deaths still to come, Dr. Deborah L. Birx, a member of the White House coronavirus task force, heard her cellphone ring. It was Dr. Scott Rivkees, the Florida surgeon general. He was distraught.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘Barbenheimer’ Is a Huge Hollywood Moment and Maybe the Last for a While
description: The big launch of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” should have been a celebratory moment, but an industry on pause has darkened the mood.
content: The film industry’s happiest weekend in a long time may also be its last happy weekend for many months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: A Mystery in the E.R.? Ask Dr. Chatbot for a Diagnosis.
description: At a medical school in Boston, instructors are using ChatGPT in training exercises to help teach students how to think like doctors.
content: The patient was a 39-year-old woman who had come to the emergency department at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston. Her left knee had been hurting for several days. The day before, she had a fever of 102 degrees. It was gone now, but she still had chills. And her knee was red and swollen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Gunman in Fargo Attack Looked Up Mass Shootings Online, Officials Say
description: The slain gunman had a large stockpile of weapons and had made troubling online searches before the shooting in North Dakota that left an officer dead.
content: The gunman who the authorities say killed a Fargo, N.D., police officer and wounded two other officers and a civilian on July 14 had searched online for mass shootings before the attack, officials announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: As Tensions Rise, Zelensky Pushes for Way to Ship Grain Through Black Sea
description: The Ukrainian leader said he had spoken with the NATO chief and the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, a key mediator between Russia and Ukraine since the full-scale invasion began last February.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was pushing forward with diplomatic efforts on Saturday to reopen the Black Sea to Ukraine’s grain shipments, strategizing with NATO’s chief a day after discussing with the Turkish president the collapse of a deal that allowed ships to bypass Russia’s blockade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, July 15-21
description: If you succeeded in getting this week’s toughest word, don’t be shy — feel free to trumpet it.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: A Mental Health Crisis. An Officer’s Gun. A Too-Common Tragedy.
description: The death of Melissa Perez in San Antonio is renewing vexing questions about how police deal with people who have mental health issues.
content: The San Antonio Police Department, like the police in other cities, has a Mental Health Unit available around the clock to respond to calls that require trained, empathetic responses and support for people in distress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Urvashi Uberoy and Keith Collins
title: New Yorkers Got Broken Promises. Developers Got 20 Million Sq. Ft.
description: It was supposed to be an even trade: Permission to raise larger buildings in exchange for airy, open spaces for the public. The reality has been different.
content: It was supposed to be an even trade: Permission to raise larger buildings in exchange for airy, open spaces for the public. The reality has been different.
source.name: The New York Times
